statement.text: Type 2 endoleaks most commonly arise from lumbar arteries (60-70% of cases) and the inferior mesenteric artery (25-30% of cases), with these vessels maintaining perfusion via extensive collateral networks from the internal iliac, intercostal, and mesenteric arterial systems.
statement.formal: Source Vessels: Lumbar arteries (paired, L1-L5) >> IMA (midline, L3) > Accessory renal arteries > Median sacral artery | Collateral inflow determines Type 2 persistence

explanation.intuition: Think of the abdominal aorta like a main highway with multiple exit ramps (branch vessels). When you place the stent-graft, you close these exits from the main road. But these exits are also connected to a network of side streets (collaterals). Blood can still reach these exits by taking the side streets, then flow backward into the old aneurysm space.
explanation.key_insight: Understanding which vessels cause Type 2 endoleaks and their collateral sources is critical for planning embolization procedures - you need to block both the vessel feeding the sac AND its collateral supply to achieve durable closure.
explanation.technical_details: The likelihood of Type 2 endoleak correlates with the number and caliber of patent branch vessels. Each lumbar artery pair receives collateral flow from the ipsilateral internal iliac artery via the iliolumbar artery. The IMA receives collateral flow from the superior mesenteric artery via the marginal artery of Drummond and from the internal iliac arteries via the superior hemorrhoidal artery.

normal_anatomy.distribution: Paraspinal muscles, spinal canal, abdominal wall

collateral_sources.primary: Internal iliac artery via iliolumbar artery
collateral_sources.clinical_significance: Most important collateral, often targeted in embolization
Can maintain flow to upper lumbar arteries

type2_characteristics.typical_pattern: Flow-through lesion (one lumbar inflow, another outflow)
type2_characteristics.imaging_appearance: Paired posterior foci on CT, best seen on sagittal/coronal
type2_characteristics.embolization_target: Both feeding and draining lumbars, often via iliolumbar approach

normal_anatomy.origin: Anterior aorta at L3 level, ~3-4 cm above bifurcation
normal_anatomy.distribution: Left transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid, proximal rectum

collateral_sources.primary: Superior mesenteric artery via marginal artery (Arc of Riolan)
collateral_sources.pathway: Midgut to hindgut anastomosis along colon
collateral_sources.clinical_significance: Robust collateral in most patients, maintains IMA flow

collateral_sources.secondary: Internal iliac arteries via superior hemorrhoidal arteries

type2_characteristics.typical_pattern: Single vessel inflow or flow-through via hemorrhoidal connection
type2_characteristics.imaging_appearance: Anterior midline vessel on sagittal CT
type2_characteristics.embolization_considerations: Risk of bowel ischemia if SMA collaterals inadequate - assess carefully

clinical_implications.patency_rate: Patent in 40-50% of AAA patients pre-EVAR
clinical_implications.preoperative_assessment: Some surgeons test clamp IMA during open repair
clinical_implications.embolization_safety: Generally safe if good SMA collaterals demonstrated

normal_anatomy.clinical_significance: May be covered by EVAR if arising from aneurysm

type2_characteristics.collateral_sources: Main renal artery branches, capsular vessels
Internal iliac arteries, lateral sacral arteries

high_risk_features.mechanism: More space for thrombus to accommodate branch flow

preoperative_considerations: Document patent branch vessels on pre-EVAR imaging
Inform patient of endoleak risk if many patent branches
embolization_planning: Identify all feeding AND draining vessels
Assess bowel collaterals before IMA embolization

related.relationship: Branch vessel anatomy determines Type 2 pathophysiology

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, 9th Edition
sources.chapter: Endovascular Repair of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms

sources.citation: Collateral pathways in type 2 endoleaks: implications for treatment

learning_objectives: Identify the common source vessels for Type 2 endoleaks
Understand the collateral pathways maintaining branch vessel flow
Apply anatomic knowledge to embolization procedure planning
Predict Type 2 risk based on pre-EVAR imaging
clinical_pearls: Lumbar arteries are PAIRED - always look for both feeding and draining vessels
IMA collaterals via SMA are usually excellent - embolization rarely causes ischemia
The iliolumbar artery is your friend and enemy - great for transarterial access, but maintains lumbar flow
Count patent lumbars on pre-op CT - ≥3 pairs = high Type 2 risk
